content.description:
Quality sport climb. High first bolt, but easy climbing leads to increasing difficulty towards the top.

To the right of Generation Gap.
7 bolts.

Start on the large flake and climb up through the stripes.

7 bolts

climbs.name: Generation Gap
climbs.fa: Howie Richardson, Tony Richardson, Robin Mounsey 1991

content.description:
Fairly straight forward quality climb with a little undercling at the crux.

Two lines to the right of Rejuvenation.
6 bolts.

Good climb with a solid looking pin for the third bolt (May 2015).

One light right of 'S Cool Wall.
7 bolts and 1 pin.

Technical and powerful crux on the bulge above the mini roof. Easy terrain above this! Watch for your belayer getting eaten by mosquitosÂ 


Bolts

A staight line over several bulges. Challenging right off the ground and sustained tricky climbing right up the fourth or fifth bolt. The difficulty eases off for the final 5 metres or so.

The furthest climb on the right side of The Kid's Cliff.
7 bolts.

climbs.name: Rejuvenation
climbs.fa: Howie Richardson, Dave Hetherington, Doug Kenyon 1992

content.description:
Start up an easy flake over a bulge onto a ledge and traverse left. Continue straight up to finish.

From the left side of the crag, this is the second bolted line.
5 bolts.

This is a good climb with some challenging moves right off the ground. Past this you climb up a flake on the left and on top of it where easy climbing to the fourth bolt provides a bit of scary huge fall potential. A cam placement in the flake would probably make a lot of 5.10- leaders feel much better about those last moves towards that fourth bolt. After this the climb steers hard right and around a smooth bulge the back ten feet to the left to finish. A few long draws would ease up the rope drag through this section.

From the right side, this is the second climb over.
7 bolts. Consider a cam for the flake in the runout section between the third and fourth bolt.

This crag contains a dozen or more climbs that I would characterize as mostly polished slab climbing. The typical positive edges found on a lot of the rock at Skaha seem to have not found their way here, or at least those similar edges are more worn down and weathered which tends to make these climbs feel a bit tricky. There are some steeper sections of climbing, but lower angle features dominate. There is an array of 5.9 and 5.10 climbing to be found here, plus a couple harder 5.11 and 5.12 climbs for those fans of thin, technical, and devious hard routes. All of the climbs are around 20 metres in length. 
  
 Kid's Cliff is a little bit out of the way but is still on the main loop trail around the Skaha conservation area. From what I understand, before the previous parking area was developed there used to be a main access trail coming in from this direction and at that time this crag saw a lot more activity.
